Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real functions of time t, governed by \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\), respectively, with A and B being constant matrices. We evaluate the effects of a Fourier transform defined by \\( f(z) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-2\pi i \omega t} z(t) dt \\) on z(t).

If the Fourier transform \\( f(z) \\) is applied to \\( z(t) \\) starting from t = 0 and evolves naturally under \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\) without any external intervention, will the Fourier transform of z(t) at t = T differ from that of the initial conditions directly evolved to t = T?
Explanation: The application of the Fourier transform does not alter the physical evolution of \\( z(t) \\), it only provides a transformation into the frequency domain. The dynamics governed by A and B remain unaffected by the Fourier transform itself, hence the spectrum at t = T should depend only on these dynamics and initial conditions.
